questions.question_text: A network support technician takes a call from an office manager who wants to change the wireless security key on the access point in that particular office. The office manager explains that a label on the access point indicates it has an IP address of 10.0.100.2. Which of the following should the technician use to connect securely to the access point to make the change?

discussion.content: every time it says "connect securely" the answer seems to be SSH

comments.content: SSH is typically, if not always, the answer in the context of remotely connecting to network devices, such as routers. Most of them use Linux, which precludes RDP (Windows only).
Joe is right, http is not secure.
On this one though it specifically asks to connect securely and https is not an option. The only secure option is SSH.

discussion.content: Normally we open wap by writing ip address in a browser so the answer should be http.

questions.question_text: A technician is troubleshooting a computer that may have some corrupt operating system files. Which of the following command line tools should the technician use to check these files?

discussion.content: Answer should be D

comments.content: It's not about being "more right". Using chkdsk is completely wrong; you want to check the system files (D: sfc) not check the physical integrity of the disk (chkdsk).
Initially I thought chkdisk as answer, but after doing some research you are probably more right.

discussion.content: Guys I think the keyword here is, "CHECK".... I believe chkdisk you can run without having the fix automatically applied while with sfc the fix is applied after scanning.

comments.content: I agree it only states that there MAY be some corrupt files so the CHKDSK is being used to test the theory. I guess its based on the troubleshooting steps from core 1
and sfc is the system file CHECKer! D. is correct
yup, also if you just run sfc, it actually doesn't tells you which files may be corrupt. It just shows that there are corrupt files and it has been fix. So Chkdsk is a good option for this one

discussion.content: diskpart: This is a tool that helps you manage your computer’s drives (like hard drives or partitions). It’s not typically used for checking or fixing corrupt system files. . sfc: This stands for “System File Checker”. It’s a tool that scans all protected system files and replaces corrupted files with a cached copy that is located in a compressed folder at %WinDir%\System32\dllcache

Selected Answer: D
Definitely not scandisk. It is for physical disk health. System File checkenwillbdo the job
The Answer is D: sfc checks the system file. chkdsk checks the harddrive. The answer is in the question.
the answer is b because chkdisk is the first thing you check first and then sfc.

answer is clearly D
sfc - system file checker, checks for corrupt operating system files and drives and repair/replace them.
chkdsk checks for issues and bad sectors on the storage drive.

Selected Answer: D
Chkdsk is to verify file system and not specific to OS. But the quetions says Specifics about OS so SFC should be right answer .

See this website, it is possible that the answer (b) is the correct one.
Here he explains that (Chkdsk) is the first option to use if it does not solve the problems, but it is solved, then go to the command (SFC).

https://www.makeuseof.com/difference-between-chkdsk-sfc-and-dism-in-windows-10/

I also found this fragment in the book of Mike Meryers

"The Chkdsk (Checkdisk) Command Scans, Detets, And Repires File System" ISSUES AND ERRORS. You Can Run The Chkdsk Utility From A Command Prompt With The Switches /F And /R. The /f switch attempts to fix file system -related error, While the /r switch attempts to locate and repair bad sectors. "

The answer is 100% D- System File Checker. All the rookies will clearly say B is the right answer which is not, most of the people haven't read any book or watched a single video, they just come here to make guesses rather than helping

Selected Answer: D
it's D

Selected Answer: D
It is SFC. SFC scans the integrity of your OS. It should be used prior to running DISM.
It is SFC. SFC scans for corrupted files. CHKDSK scans the actual disk for bad sectors and other damages.

Answer is B.
CHKDSK is a command to check the file system and files on your disk. It can tell you about the drive health of your disk and filesystem. SFC [System File Checker] is a tool to correct Windows software in your OS by using a secured Windows Storage folder to get corrected versions for system files.

Selected Answer: D
Has to be D, stop giving to the wrong answers if you are unsure morons. Giving people misinformation is a real dick thing to do.

Selected Answer: D
Answer should be D

I'm leaning towards SFC as well. People say keyword is "Check" however it mentions "operating" system files as well as "command tools" not "commands" meaning the SFC tool (with all it's options) should be correct. Everywhere else online also marks chkdsk as correct though.....

sfc
The Windows sfc (System File Checker) command scans, detects, and restores important Windows system files, folders, and paths. Techs often turn to sfc when Windows isn’t quite working correctly and use it to find and fix critical Windows system files that have become corrupt. If you run sfc and it finds issues, it attempts to replace corrupted or missing files from cached DLLs (backups of those system files) located in the Windows\System32\Dllcache\ directory. Without getting very deep into the mad science involved, just know that you can use sfc to correct corruption. To run sfc from a command prompt, enter sfc /scannow. To familiarize yourself with sfc’s switches, enter sfc /?
- Mike Meyers ebook

SFC is technically correct, but the command SFC on its own wont do anything as it needs to be followed by an additional command which is not given as an answer. So for this question i`d say B is MOST correct

"Whereas CHKDSK finds and fixes errors in the file system of your hard drive, SFC (System File Checker) specifically scans and repairs Windows system files. If it detects that a file has been corrupted or modified, SFC automatically replaces that file with the correct version."

comments.content: sfc /verifyonly command to scan but not repair

sfc /verifyonly (no repair) this command only do checking

Does CompTIA want you to troubleshoot and fix the files or just troubleshoot the issue and check the files and NOT fix it? The question here is vague, it simply asks to check the files and NOT fix them. So this answer is CHKDSK!
I'm still struggling to distinguish between SFC and chkdsk. SMH

comments.content: It's easy. Just think of chkdsk as checking (and potentially fixing) the physical integrity of the disk, while sfc checks (and can fix) the integrity of system files. Completely different.

discussion.content: chkdsk is referred to as a tool most often while, SFC tends to be referred to as a utility or sub category of tool same difference but im going with chkdsk because of verbiage. and you are checking file not really repairing them for errors.
System File Checker (sfc)- Utility in Microsoft Windows that allows users to scan for and restore corruptions in Windows system files. keywords= corrupt, system files. Correct answer is D.
CHKDSK is the correct answer! "...Whereas CHKDSK finds and fixes errors in the file system of your hard drive, SFC (System File Checker) specifically scans and repairs Windows system files..."
SFC is the correct answer! "...Whereas CHKDSK finds and fixes errors in the file system of your hard drive, SFC (System File Checker) specifically scans and repairs Windows system files..."

Typically if the wrong answer is indicated and is actually on the exam, other exam prep websites will have the same incorrect answer. This is the first one i've seen that has zero additional websites stating the wrong answer. Going with SFC

ANSWER D.SFC 
OBJ-1.4: If some Windows functions aren't working or Windows crashes, then you can use the System File Checker (SFC) to scan Windows and restore your system files.

That's correcr, It should be D.sfc. 

This is what Microsoft says about this issue:
"The sfc /scannow command will scan all protected system files, and replace corrupted files with a cached copy that is located in a compressed folder at %WinDir%\System32\dllcache. The %WinDir% placeholder represents the Windows operating system folder" 

Source: 
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/use-the-system-file-checker-tool-to-repair-missing-or-corrupted-system-files-79aa86cb-ca52-166a-92a3-966e85d4094e#:~:text=The%20sfc%20%2Fscannow%20command%20will,the%20Windows%20operating%20system%20folder.

I have tried with most of the questions to identify why an intended designated correct response is correct overall according to the website and or question producers. This question I'm finding that unfortunately more difficult to do. Thanks in advance if you respond to this.

comments.content: sfc is system file checker. so you are correct. chkdsk just checks for bad sectors, dism uses the internet to pull up needed files to fix issues, may help sfc if it is still unable to restore them

and are able to hopefully able to help resolve this situation.
Many thanks.

It's definitely D. SFC checks Windows system files which would be the operating files in this case. Chkdsk checks file system logical files and if the correct switch is used, will also check for bad sectors, etc.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) defines what actions
employees may or may not perform on company equipment.

questions.question_text: What a user is allowed to do on a computer network would be addressed in:

discussion.content:
NTFS permissions that are assigned to a folder are automatically inherited by the files and subfolders created under the folder. To prevent this from happening, open the Security page and select Advanced, then select the Permission tab. In Windows 7, select the Change permissions button to proceed.

Select the Disable inheritance button.

On Windows 10 Enterprise:
You can click on any folder or file > on the top toolbar click Share > Advanced Security and on the bottom is the Disable Inheritance button.

Selected Answer: D
Inheritance is always the answer on any question !
Inheritance is a concept, not a setting. Hopefully the original phrasing is asking about concept.

comments.content: I was wrong. It is a setting. My apologies

discussion.content: Where is inheritance located?

questions.question_text: A systems administrator creates a new folder in the user profile. The administrator wants it to have different NTFS permissions than its parent folder. Which of the following settings should the administrator change?

discussion.content: Is the answer A because the WiFi is connecting to another public page that requires authentication similar to a public WiFi location
He is redirected to a captive portal, which simply wants to authorize him to use a wireless connection. He tries to connect to the wrong SSID. Answer is A
why not D?

comments.content: Because B4 you troubleshoot the gateway, FIRST make sure your wireless connection to the intended SSID is correct. CompTIA has thrown a few questions that ask you what your FIRST step will be...which is, verify the connection first.

choices.C: The data speeds from the user's ISP
choices.B: The signal strength from the ISP regional satellite

questions.question_text: A SOHO user is working on a laptop, but the wireless connection indicator is showing a limited connection. Each time the user tries to access a website, the browser redirects to an unfamiliar authentication page. Which of the following should the user check to troubleshoot the cause of the issue?
